description: Immunization protects against dangerous diseases. A child who is not immunized is more likely to become sick, permanently disabled or undernourished, and could possibly die.
title: Immunization protects against dangerous diseases. A child who is not immunized is more likely to become sick, permanently disabled or undernourished, and could possibly die.
content:
Immunization protects children against some of the most dangerous diseases of childhood. A child is immunized by vaccines, which are injected or given by mouth. The vaccines work by building up the child’s defenses against diseases. Immunization only works if given before the disease strikes.

A child who is not immunized is very likely to get measles, whooping cough and many other diseases that can kill. Children who survive these diseases are weakened and may not grow well. They may be permanently disabled. They may die later from malnutrition and other illnesses.
